thread.title: Exclusive: New Brexit survey reveals whether people in Leicester want Britain to remain in single market

author: leicestermercury
title: Exclusive: New Brexit survey reveals whether people in Leicester want Britain to remain in single market
text:
Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get Daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
A new Brexit survey shows 50% of Leicester Mercury readers believe Britain will be better off economically inside Europe. 
As well as this, 56% said Britain should continue to be part of the single European market. 
The figures show a split between those who voted Leave and those who voted Remain in the referendum. 
Among Leave voters, 9% think Britain is better off economically in Europe, while nearly a quarter of these voters (23%) think we should continue to be part of the Single Market. 
Remain voters are, unsurprisingly, much more likely to think continuing close ties with Europe is a good idea, with 84% saying Britain is better off economically inside Europe and 82% saying we should continue to be part of the Single Market. 
Three-fifths of those surveyed on the site (59%) said they were not happy with the status of Brexit negotiations at the moment, with just a fifth (22%) saying they were happy (the rest weren't sure). Read More Leicester residents have been backing calls for safe standing in stadiums 
Regardless of how those surveyed voted in the referendum, they were more likely to be unhappy than happy with the way negotiations are going. 
Among those who said they voted Leave, 42% are unhappy with the status of negotiations compared to 36% who were happy. 
More than three-quarters of those who voted Remain (72%) said they were unhappy, compared to 10% who said they were happy. Read More Contracts "being lost" due to poor investment in Leicestershire railways, roads and digital 
However, most of those surveyed said they would still stick with how they voted - 87% of Leave voters and 92% of Remain voters. 
Leave voters were more likely to say they would not vote in the same way now, with one in 16 Leave voters saying they'd act differently (6%) compared to one in 25 Remain voters (4%). The study, run in partnership with Google Surveys, was completed online by 1500 people who visited the Leicester Mercury website Like us on Facebook
